bibl.title: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to J.F. Siler, August 31, 1950

div1.p: Hench is concerned about Kean's condition and prospective surgery, and would like more information because he believes a different surgical procedure is more appropriate.

div1.head: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to J.F. Siler, August 31, 1950
div1.opener:
August 31, 1950
Colonel Joseph F. Siler, President
Gorgas Memorial Institute
1835 Eye Street, N. W.
Washington 6, D. C.
My dear Colonel Siler:
div1.p:
I am quite concerned to hear of General
Kean's trouble. You say that his physician thinks
they must remove the entire prostate.

I should not be interfering but because
of my great esteem and affection for General Kean
I am worried. You infer that the enlargement is
benign, not malignant. It is my impression here
that our men rarely any longer remove the entire
prostate for benign enlargement with retention.
Instead, they do a much simpler operation called
the punch operation.

Do you have any way, without involving
yourself or me in any unethical dealings, to find
out why they are planning to remove the whole
prostate.
div1.closer: Sincerely yours, P. S. Hench, M. D. PSH:alc
